item.title: Contracting and quality upgrading: evidence from a pilot experiment in Senegal
COVID-19 awareness and impacts among Senegalese groundnut farmers
item.description: Date: June 25, 2020 This post is intended to share rapid results from an ongoing phone survey in Senegal. The research, part of a larger project on contract structure and technology adoption by groundut farmers, is joint with Tanguy Bernard, Laura Schechter, and Ouambi Yameogo. The research is supported financially by the CGIAR Research Program on Policies, Institutions, and Markets and the Agricultural Technology Adoption Initiative (ATAI). Due to the ongoing COVID-19 crisis, we decided to adapt a planned survey to measure some impacts of the crisis on groundnut farmers in Senegal.

item.title: Measurement error, validation data, and program evaluation
Measuring willingness to pay for reliable electricity: evidence from Senegal
Spillovers without social interactions in urban sanitation
Using market mechanisms to increase the take-up of improved sanitation
Pricing complexity and consumer behavior: evidence from a lab experiment
The reform of energy subsidies in Iran: The role of cash transfers
Can smallholder extension transform African agriculture?
item.description: Agricultural productivity in Sub-Saharan Africa lags far behind all other regions of the world. A long list of policy experiments has yielded more evidence on what fails than on what works. We analyze a randomized control trial of a rare scaled-up success story: One Acre Fundâ€™s small farmer program. Much like anti-poverty “graduation” interventions, the program aims to relax multiple constraints to productivity simultaneously. We show that participation causes statistically and economically significant increases in output, yields, and profits.
